titleStmt.title: Istishara Harran
SHAWI Corpus
titleStmt.funder: Funded by the FWF Austrian Science Fund under the number P 33574

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: "Consultation," let's say it exists in our religion. There is something called "consultation," which is when a person is unable to make a decision about something.
"Consultation," let's say someone is doing something and says, "I want to do a 'consultation.'" I have done a "consultation" for myself.
For example, there is a problem with my throat, and now I am scared because they want to remove a piece from my throat. I am afraid of that.
"How will they take it, I wonder? With local anesthesia or without? I wonder if the needle will hurt or not? I wonder what will happen to me?"
I got up and intended, I said: 'Oh my Lord,' and I prayed two rakʕas. I performed ablution and prayed two rakʕas.
I slept on the 'consultation,' I slept on the consultation and said: 'Oh my Lord, if this is good for me, I want to see a sign (ʕarka) in the morning.'
The 'sign' that I want to see, if it is good, show it to me, and if it is bad, show it to me as well.
And at night, my mother-in-law brought me, they say, if it is good, I will see either the color white or green, but if it is bad, I will see either the color red or black."
Ah! And at night, my mother-in-law filled a basket with mint, and I asked her: This mint you brought, is it clean or dirty?"
And she says: 'By God, eat from it, it is clean, I washed it several times. It is clean, you can eat from it.' When I woke up in the morning, I said: 'Okay, I can go for the surgery.'
I saw a good dream, thank God, it was true. How did I sleep? They brought me a thin needle, and it didn't even hurt, I didn't feel it.
They took a piece from my thyroid in three places. This is how 'istišāṛa' (consultation) works. 'istišāṛa' is also present in our religion.
